text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with my take on Carolina style
barbecue sauce and this style of sauce
is known for its vinegary peppery
characteristics sometimes mustard
sometimes not mustard depends on what
part of the state you're from I guess
I've never been there and here we go now
because I'm using apple cider vinegar as
my acid in the sauce I decided to cube
up one green apple and with just a
little bit of oil maybe a half of a
teaspoon I just started to caramelize
that a little bit in a saucepan to which
I added a couple tablespoons of brown
sugar by the way yes I should have used
the freakishly small wooden spoon here
why didn't I I'm so mad but it's too
late so we're just going to cook it like
this over medium heat for like two
minutes until the sugar started to boil
and bubble just like that and at that
point we're going to add our apple cider
vinegar I'm going to bring that to a
simmer I'm going to lower the heat to
very low I'm going to cover it and we're
going to cook that until the apples
basically just fall apart and to help
things out I just used a potato masher
to keep crushing them and smashing them
until like I said they basically just
disappeared into the vinegar so I'll be
honest I didn't really time that but I
think it took about a half hour all
right I'm going to turn off the heat I'm
going to add lots of black pepper lots
of red pepper flakes
okay these Carolina vinegar-based sauces
are quite quite liberally spiced with
pepper and then the only other addition
here is yellow mustard do not use good
stone-ground brown or Dijon mustard or
anything like that I want you to find
yellow prepared mustard the cheaper the
better in fact if you can find generic
mustard use it okay so once the mustard
is in there we are basically done with
the sauce and yes that is the worst
looking thing you've ever seen true okay
so we do have one small minor step left
and that is to blend this completely
smooth okay so throw that in the blender
we want to liquefy that
we want that mustard emulsified in there
we want that Apple just completely
smoothed out until we have something
that looks like this way better looking
in fact pretty good-looking if you ask
me and what are we going to do with this
so many things we could use it as a
condiment of course just straight like
that but it's also great as a basting
sauce like you'd use other types of
barbecue sauce and of course the same
system applies we're going to brush this
on at the end of the cooking so it
doesn't all burn so these pork chops
were very close to being done I brushed
it on each side and it really did work
beautifully by the way those are
molasses brined pork chops which I will
demo in another video so stay tuned
these Carolina style sauces are so
intensely vinegary and peppery and in
this case a little mustard II that you
don't need a lot okay so you just see me
drizzling down a little bit there a
little bit on top perfect and it really
works so well that sharp peppery bite
just counteracting that smoky rich fatty
Mead with a perfect perfect combination
so there you go a little change of pace
from our usual tomato-based barbecue
sauces I hope you give that a try all
the ingredients are on food wishes calm
as usual and as always enjoy
